---
title: "Week 2: Writing Code"
author: Joe Ornstein

echo: true
message: false

bibliography: references.bib

This week we introduce the statistical software that we will use to work with data this semester (R and RStudio). By the end of this module, you will learn:

-   How to write a script that loads a dataset and performs basic analyses

-   How to navigate file systems, create objects, and use functions.

-   The basic structure of dataframes, units of analyses, types of variables

-   How to interpret summary statistics of single variables (mean, variance, standard deviation)

# Reading

**DAFSS** Chapter 1

# Problem Set

This week's problem set is designed to ensure that you have R and RStudio properly installed on your computer, and that you can write code that loads data, describes it, and performs a few basic analyses.

We will analyze a dataset from an experiment conducted in Michigan in 2006 [@gerberSocialPressureVoter2008]. In that experiment, voters were randomly assigned to receive a postcard with a "social pressure" message, describing the recipient's voting history and the voting history of their neighbors. The dataset we will use is called "voting.csv", available [here](data/voting.csv). The following table shows the names and descriptions of the variables in the dataset.

| variable  | description                                                                                     |
|-----------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| *birth*   | year of birth of registered voter                                                               |
| *message* | whether the registered voter was assigned to receive the social pressure message: "yes" or "no" |
| *voted*   | whether registered voter voted in the August 2006 election: 1=voted, 0=didn't vote              |

Write an R script that performs the following analyses, in order. You can use comments in your script to respond to questions.

1.  Download the [voting.csv](data/voting.csv) file and put it into your DSS folder. Read the dataset into R and save it as an object called `voting`. (10 points)

2.  Use the function `head()` to view the first few observations of the dataset. (10 points)

3.  How many observations are there in total? What is the unit of analysis? (10 points)

4.  What is the average value of the variable *birth*? Interpret this number. (10 points)

5.  What is the average value of the variable *voted*? Interpret this number. (10 points)

6.  **Bonus.** Install the `tinytex` package by entering the following lines of code into the `R` console.[^1]


    ::: {.cell}
    
    ```{.r .cell-code}
    install.packages('tinytex')
    tinytex::install_tinytex()
    ```
    :::


    Once this is installed, you can compile your `R` script and its output as a PDF by clicking "Compile Report" in RStudio. Submit this PDF report to eLC. (10 points)

[^1]: Not the `R` script! If you install a package in the script then it will reinstall the package every time you run the script, which is time-consuming.

# Additional Resources

-   [Teacup Giraffes](https://tinystats.github.io/teacups-giraffes-and-statistics/01_introToR.html): Intro To R

-   An interactive [tutorial](https://learnr-examples.shinyapps.io/ex-setup-r/) if you need additional help setting up R and RStudio
